coverText: Appraisal of the fee simple interest in the subject property: a 45,000 SF Class A office building located at 2400 Commerce Drive, Austin, Texas. Prepared in conformity with USPAP and the 2024-2025 edition of the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

blocks.text: February 15, 2025

Mr. James Chen, Senior Vice President
Meridian Commercial Real Estate
500 Congress Avenue, Suite 1200
Austin, TX 78701
Re: Appraisal Report – 2400 Commerce Drive, Austin, Texas (Travis County)
Dear Mr. Chen:

Pursuant to your engagement dated January 10, 2025, we have completed an appraisal of the subject property for mortgage underwriting purposes. The subject is a three-story, Class A office building containing approximately 45,000 rentable square feet, situated on 2.8 acres in the Northwest Austin submarket.

We have inspected the subject property, reviewed relevant market data, and analyzed the three traditional approaches to value. The Sales Comparison Approach was developed using twelve recent sales of similar office properties in the submarket. The Income Approach was developed using stabilized potential gross income, market-derived vacancy and expense assumptions, and a market-derived capitalization rate. The Discounted Cash Flow Analysis was prepared using a ten-year projection with a discount rate and terminal cap rate supported by market evidence.

Our analysis utilized the Sales Comparison, Income, and Discounted Cash Flow approaches to value. The conclusion of market value is set forth in the Letter of Transmittal and is supported by the analyses and exhibits contained in this report. This appraisal was prepared in conformity with the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice (USPAP) and is intended for use by Meridian CRE and the named lender only.
Please contact the undersigned with any questions or requests for clarification.

Respectfully submitted,

Valuation Partners, Inc.
Sarah Mitchell, MAI, AI-GRS
Managing Director

Property Address: 2400 Commerce Drive, Austin, Travis County, Texas 78758
Client: Meridian Commercial Real Estate
Intended Use: Mortgage financing
Effective Date of Appraisal: February 1, 2025
Report Date: February 15, 2025

The foregoing value conclusion represents the market value of the fee simple estate as if vacant and available for its highest and best use, and reflects the property's condition and market position as of the effective date. Limiting conditions, assumptions, and certifications are set forth in the addendum.

This report presents an appraisal of the fee simple interest in the subject property, a 45,000 SF Class A office building located at 2400 Commerce Drive in the Northwest Austin submarket of Austin, Texas. The appraisal was prepared for mortgage underwriting purposes at the request of Meridian Commercial Real Estate. The effective date of the appraisal is February 1, 2025.

The subject was constructed in 2018 and underwent a lobby and common-area renovation in 2022. It is situated on a 2.8-acre site with surface parking for 180 vehicles. As of the effective date, the property was approximately 92% occupied with a diversified tenant roster and a weighted average remaining lease term of approximately 4.2 years. In-place rents are generally at or slightly below current market, supporting stable near-term income with modest mark-to-market opportunity upon rollover.

After reconciliation of the three approaches to value, the conclusion of market value as of the effective date is $12,750,000 (Twelve Million Seven Hundred Fifty Thousand Dollars). This conclusion gives primary weight to the Sales Comparison and Income approaches, with secondary weight to the DCF, and is intended for use by the client and the named lender in connection with the contemplated financing.

Key risks and considerations include exposure to lease rollover in years 3–5, submarket competition from new supply, and interest-rate sensitivity. These are reflected in the cap rate and discount rate assumptions applied in the analysis. No unusual or extraordinary assumptions were required.

The subject property is located at 2400 Commerce Drive in Austin, Travis County, Texas. The site is in the Northwest Austin office corridor, approximately 12 miles north of downtown Austin and 8 miles from Austin-Bergstrom International Airport. The location benefits from frontage on Commerce Drive with signalized access to US 183 and MoPac Expressway (Loop 1) within one mile.

rows: Lot 4, Block A, Commerce Park Phase 2, Travis County, Texas
Generally rectangular; buildable area adequate for current improvements
Gently sloping; site has been graded; no significant floodplain
Dedicated curb cut on Commerce Drive; signal at intersection with Park Plaza Dr
City water and sewer; electric (Austin Energy); gas (Atmos); fiber available

blocks.text: The subject is within the City of Austin extraterritorial jurisdiction and is served by Austin Independent School District. Adjacent uses include office, retail, and light industrial. The area has seen substantial development over the past decade, with strong demand for well-located office product. Traffic counts on Commerce Drive exceed 25,000 vehicles per day, providing strong visibility and accessibility.

blocks.caption: Aerial view of subject site and surrounding area.

blocks.text: The improvements consist of a three-story, steel-frame and masonry office building containing approximately 45,000 rentable square feet. The building was completed in 2018 and received a comprehensive lobby, elevator cab, and common-area renovation in 2022. Building systems are in good condition and are appropriate for Class A office use.

rows: Steel frame; concrete slab on grade (first floor), composite deck (upper); exterior masonry and curtain wall
Built-up membrane; 10-year warranty; HVAC units on rooftop
Office: 80 PSF live; lobby/mechanical: as required
Central VAV; 2 rooftop units per floor; tenant-controlled thermostats
Core restrooms per floor; break room sinks per floor
Full sprinkler; fire alarm; ADA-compliant egress

blocks.text: Interior finishes include glass storefront at main entry, upgraded lobby with stone and millwork (2022), and standard office build-out in tenant areas. The building offers a 4:1 parking ratio with 180 surface spaces and designated accessible and visitor stalls. Landscaping and signage are consistent with Class A standards.

The subject site is zoned LR (Limited Industrial / Office) under the City of Austin Land Development Code. Uses permitted by right include general office, research and development, and limited retail. The current use as a multi-tenant office building is a permitted use. No variances or special exceptions were relied upon for the existing improvements.

rows: Office, R&D, limited retail, supporting uses

blocks.text: Title review was not performed as part of this appraisal. The appraisal assumes marketable fee simple title subject to matters that would be disclosed by a title report. No environmental assessment was performed; the value conclusion assumes no material environmental impairment.

sections.title: 3. Highest and Best Use
sections.subtitle: As Improved and As If Vacant

blocks.text: Highest and best use is defined as the reasonably probable and legal use that is physically possible, appropriately supported, financially feasible, and that results in the highest value. The analysis is presented for the property as improved and as if vacant.

As improved: The existing Class A office improvement is the highest and best use of the property. The improvement is well-suited to the site and submarket, is legally permissible and physically appropriate, and generates a positive return. Demolition and redevelopment would not be economically justified given current construction costs and market rents.

As if vacant: The highest and best use of the land as if vacant is for development of office or mixed-use office product, consistent with zoning and surrounding uses. The site is adequate in size, configuration, and access to support the existing improvement or a similar use. Conclusion: the subject's highest and best use as improved is its current use as a multi-tenant Class A office building.

The subject is located in the Austin-Round Rock-Georgetown Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA). The MSA comprises five counties (Travis, Williamson, Hays, Bastrop, Caldwell) and is one of the fastest-growing metros in the nation, with a diverse economy anchored by technology, state government, healthcare, and education.

Major employers include the State of Texas, Dell Technologies, Apple, Tesla, Oracle, and the University of Texas at Austin. In-migration and corporate relocations have driven strong demand for office space despite recent hybrid-work adjustments.

The MSA has added over 400,000 residents in the past decade. Housing affordability pressures have increased but remain favorable relative to coastal tech markets. The regional transportation network continues to expand with toll and managed lanes, improving connectivity to the subject submarket.

blocks.caption: Subject site and Northwest Austin submarket context.

blocks.text: The Northwest Austin submarket includes the Domain, Arboretum, and surrounding corridors. It has benefited from new multifamily and retail development and improved access via SH 183 and MoPac. Class A asking rents have stabilized in the $38–42/SF full-service range with concessions of 3–6 months on 5-year terms.

Competitive supply includes several buildings completed in the 2016–2020 period, with newer product in the Domain area commanding a rent premium. Tenant demand has been strongest for suites in the 3,000–15,000 SF range. Full-service gross lease structures remain typical, with some modified gross and NNN alternatives for larger users.

blocks.title: Northwest Austin Class A Vacancy and Rent Trend

sections.title: 6. Rent Roll and Lease Summary
sections.subtitle: In-Place Income as of Effective Date

blocks.text: The following rent roll reflects all leases in place as of February 1, 2025. Total occupied space is 41,400 SF (92%). Vacant space consists of 3,600 SF on the second floor (Suite 210) and is marketed at $42/SF full-service. Lease expirations are staggered with no single year representing more than 28% of rentable area.

The following lease expiration schedule summarizes lease roll by year. Lease renewal assumptions used in the DCF are based on current market rents and historical retention rates for the building. No single tenant represents more than 10% of in-place rent.

Twelve comparable sales of Class A and Class B+ office properties in the Northwest Austin and North Central submarkets were analyzed. Adjustments were applied for location, size, age/condition, occupancy, and transaction date. The adjusted unit prices support a value range of $265–300/SF for the subject.

Location adjustments reflect proximity to major highways and amenity nodes; the subject is well-positioned relative to comps 2 and 5. Size adjustments account for economies of scale; the subject's 45,000 SF is near the median of the comparable set. Age/condition adjustments reflect the subject's 2022 renovation. Occupancy adjustments normalize for lease-up status. Time adjustments reflect modest market appreciation over the analysis period.

The mean and median adjusted unit prices are approximately $288/SF and $286/SF. Applying $283/SF to the subject's 45,000 SF yields an indicated value by the Sales Comparison Approach of $12,735,000, rounded.

The Cost Approach provides an indication of value based on the estimated cost to reproduce or replace the improvements, less depreciation, plus land value. Land value was estimated by sales of comparable development sites in the submarket. Reproduction cost was estimated using Marshall & Swift and local contractor data; depreciation was applied for physical, functional, and external factors.

The Cost Approach is given limited weight in the reconciliation because it does not directly reflect income or recent sales and is more susceptible to estimation variance. It is supportive of the conclusion that replacement cost exceeds market value, consistent with a mature market where existing product trades at a discount to replacement.

Stabilized potential gross income was estimated from the in-place rent roll and market rents for vacant space. Vacancy and credit loss was applied at 5%. Operating expenses and replacement reserves were derived from the subject's historical data and submarket norms. A market-derived cap rate was applied to stabilized NOI.

Operating expenses were built up from historical and market norms. The subject's actual expense ratio has averaged approximately 34–36% of EGI over the past three years. A 35% expense ratio is applied for stabilization, consistent with Class A suburban office in the submarket.

rows: Recent NW Austin Class A sale (Comp 2)
Recent NW Austin Class A sale (Comp 5)
CoStar cap rate survey – Austin CBD

blocks.text: A 10-year DCF was prepared using in-place rents with step-ups and market assumptions for lease rollover. Revenue growth was assumed at 2.5% annually; expense growth at 2.0%. A 9.0% discount rate and 9.25% terminal cap rate were applied, consistent with market and risk profile. The discount rate reflects the property's lease roll profile, submarket risk, and cost of capital; the terminal cap rate reflects expected market conditions at the end of the holding period.

The Sales Comparison, Income, and DCF approaches were weighted as follows. Sales Comparison is accorded 35% weight given the volume of recent comparable sales and relevance to a potential sale. The Income approach is weighted 40% as the property is income-producing and cap rates are well-supported. DCF is weighted 25% to reflect the medium-term lease roll and reversion. The Cost Approach was considered but given no weight in the final conclusion.

After consideration of the three approaches and the quality of the data, the conclusion of market value as of February 1, 2025, is rounded to $12,750,000 (Twelve Million Seven Hundred Fifty Thousand Dollars). This value represents the fee simple interest in the real property, as improved.
The following assumptions and limiting conditions apply to this appraisal and are part of the appraisal process. They do not diminish the scope of the work or the validity of the conclusion.

1. Title: The appraiser has assumed that the title to the property is good and marketable. No title search was conducted. The value conclusion assumes no liens, encumbrances, or restrictions other than those that would be typical for this type of property and that do not materially affect value.

2. Legal: The appraiser has assumed that the property is in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations. The appraiser is not an attorney and has not rendered a legal opinion. Zoning and land use were reviewed from available sources; no legal opinion is intended.

3. Environmental: No Phase I or other environmental assessment was performed. The value conclusion assumes the absence of hazardous materials or conditions that would materially affect value. If such conditions exist, the conclusion may be invalid.

4. Accuracy of Data: The appraiser has relied upon information furnished by the client, public records, and other sources believed to be reliable. No responsibility is assumed for the accuracy of such information. Rent roll and expense data were provided by the client and have not been independently verified by audit.

5. Contingent and Limiting Conditions: The appraisal is subject to the following: completion of the appraisal in accordance with the scope of work; the intended use and user; the effective date; and that the appraiser has no present or prospective interest in the property. Distribution of the report to parties other than the client and intended user may require a new engagement and scope of work.

6. Scope of Work: The scope of work for this assignment is sufficient to produce credible results. No hidden or unstated conditions were assumed. The appraiser has disclosed any significant assistance received in the development of the appraisal.

I certify that, to the best of my knowledge and belief: (1) the statements of fact contained in this report are true and correct; (2) the reported analyses, opinions, and conclusions are limited only by the reported assumptions and limiting conditions and are my personal, impartial, and unbiased professional analyses, opinions, and conclusions; (3) I have no present or prospective interest in the property that is the subject of this report and no personal interest with respect to the parties involved; (4) I have performed no services, as an appraiser or in any other capacity, regarding the property that is the subject of this report within the three-year period immediately preceding acceptance of this assignment; (5) my compensation is not contingent on the reporting of a predetermined value or direction in value; (6) my analyses, opinions, and conclusions were developed in conformity with USPAP; (7) I have made a personal inspection of the property that is the subject of this report; and (8) no one provided significant professional assistance to the person signing this certification.

Sarah Mitchell, MAI, AI-GRS
Valuation Partners, Inc.
Texas License No. 1234567890
February 15, 2025

blocks.text: Comparable 1 – 1900 N. Mopac Blvd. Three-story Class A office, 52,000 SF, completed 2019. Located on Mopac frontage with excellent visibility. Sold November 2024 for $14,560,000 ($280/SF). 88% occupied at sale. Buyer was a private institutional account; seller was a regional developer. Transaction was all-cash; marketing period approximately 90 days.

Comparable 2 – 9600 Great Hills Trail. Portion of larger campus; 38,500 SF building. Built 2017; common area renovation in 2021. Sold September 2024 for $10,780,000 ($280/SF). 94% occupied. Strong credit tenant mix. Located in Arboretum submarket with superior retail and amenity access. Used as primary comp for location and quality.

Comparable 3 – 12500 Research Blvd. 44,200 SF, 2016 vintage. Sold July 2024 for $12,176,000 ($275/SF). 91% occupied. Slightly older than subject; positive adjustment applied. Research Boulevard corridor; good access to 183 and Domain. Sale included assumption of in-place financing by buyer.

Comparable 4 – 8701 N. Capital of Texas Hwy. 41,000 SF, 2018. Sold May 2024 for $11,070,000 ($270/SF). 89% occupied. Capital of Texas (Loop 360) frontage; strong demographics. Seller motivated; slight time adjustment applied. Transaction verified through CoStar and party confirmation.

Comparable 5 – 10900 Stonelake Blvd. 48,000 SF, 2017. Sold March 2024 for $13,440,000 ($280/SF). 90% occupied. Stonelake corridor; similar tenant profile to subject. Sale price at low end of ask; 60-day marketing. Used to support cap rate and $/SF conclusion.

rows: Gross leasable area / Rentable square feet
Capitalization rate – NOI divided by value or price
Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice

blocks.text: Market value is defined as the most probable price that a property should bring in a competitive and open market under all conditions requisite to a fair sale, with the buyer and seller each acting prudently and knowledgeably, and assuming the price is not affected by undue stimulus.
